title: CASA0023 Weekly Learning Diary
text:
This is a weekly learning diary to document coursework from the module CASA0023 Remotely Sensing Cities and Environments (T2 2023).
Use the navigation bar to switch between chapters/weeks. There is also a Glossary page which collects and explains key remote sensing terms.
[Add Intro on me]
This site is built by Joe. To see more about my work visit https://github.com/joepost.
This site is built using Quarto. To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1  Introduction to Remote Sensing
text:
The topic of this week’s learning diary are an introduction to remote sensing, the principles of EMR, types of satellites and sensors, and sources of remote sensing data.
The practical session for this week introduced methods for extracting open access remote sensing data, including Sentinel data from the ESA’s Copernicus Open Access Hub and Landsat data from the USGS EarthExplorer.

title: 2  Week 2
text: To view this presentation full-screen, click here.

title: 1  Introduction to Remote Sensing
text:
1.1 Summary
There is a wide variety of types of remote sensors and remote sensing data, and an equally wide variation in application. Some examples include:



Earth Observation Data Source
Operator
Application Examples




Dynamic World
Google Earth Engine (GEE) app, developed jointly by Google and the World Resources Institute.
Real-time, high resolution (~10m) land cover


Landsat
NASA/USGS
- Urban/green space coverage - Urban heat island - Illegal logging - Natural disasters (bushfire, flooding)


Sentinel
ESA (European Space Agency)
- Pollution - Illegal logging - Urban heat island
- Oceanic monitoring - Natural disasters




1.1.1 What is remote sensing?
At its simplest, remote sensing is the collection of data or information about an entity (such as an object or geographic area) from a distance. In practice, this usually refers to the use of airborne or orbiting sensors designed to measure certain properties of electromagnetic energy exiting an object/area (Jensen 2015).
